messageBody:
At 06:44 AM 16/11/01, you wrote:
>Hi
>Thanks for the detailed reply.
>
>Can you help me out on the second question .. How do I write test cases for
>event driven program ?
>For e.g. I have a class A.
>This has three functions
>1. public boolean ConnectURL();
>This function connects to a particular URL and loads the details onto the
>screen. If this is successful, it returns true else false.
>2. public void Initialisation();
>This functions initializes some parameters
>3. public boolean Save(Object obj);
>This function saves the details on the screen and if successful, it returns
>true, else false.

Yuk! Horrible naming - the customary naming convention is for lowercase
method names. (There's a pdf on sun's customary coding conventions - you
can download it from Sun).



> In my test class, I will be writing test methods for all these functions.
>1. Do I need to write a test method for the second function that is just
>doing some initialization. If so, how will I write that ?

You should definitely test the initialisation - assuming it actually does
something "interesting". You might find that you need to add some get/set
methods to do so, though.


>2. For the first function, I will write a test method as follows
>public boolean testConnectURl() {
> A obj1;
> boolean b = obj1.ConnectURL();
> /// How do I write an assert statement after this ?
>}


assertTrue("Connection failed?", b);

or

URL myURL = objl.getURL();
// connect, test content a la httpunit.



>I have seen the archive of all the messages but I am not clear on how I
>write test classes for event driven programs.


The same as any other way. Don't forget that unit testing is not about
testing program flow - it's about testing how a class works at a "unit"
level. This is (often) taken to mean testing methods/functions.
